causes: Dutch efforts to break Portuguese monopoly on the spice trade
Portuguese control of key trading ports in Asia, Africa, and the Americas
Dutch independence from Spain and their aim to weaken Spanish-Portuguese power
Expansion of the Dutch East India Company (VOC) and Dutch West India Company (WIC)
events_leading_up_to_war: Dutch revolt against Spanish rule (Eighty Years' War)
Union of the Portuguese and Spanish crowns (Iberian Union, 1580–1640)
Dutch naval expeditions targeting Portuguese trade routes

result.general: Portuguese strategic victory, Dutch tactical victories in some regions
territorial_changes: Dutch gained control over Ceylon (Sri Lanka) and parts of the East Indies
Portuguese successfully defended Brazil and Angola
Portuguese regained key positions in India

allies: Local rulers in the Spice Islands

Dutch.troops: Varied, with thousands deployed in multiple theaters

Portuguese.troops: Reinforcements from Iberia and local colonies
Portuguese.warships: Strong naval presence, bolstered by Spanish support pre-1640

major_battles.name: Battle of Guararapes
major_battles.description: Decisive battles that led to the Dutch expulsion from Brazil by Portuguese and indigenous forces.

major_battles.name: Siege of Malacca
major_battles.description: Dutch forces captured the strategic city of Malacca from the Portuguese, securing control over key spice trade routes.

major_battles.name: Battle of Goa
major_battles.description: Dutch blockade failed to take the Portuguese stronghold of Goa.

major_battles.name: Battle of Colombo
major_battles.description: Dutch and their allies from the Kingdom of Kandy captured Colombo from the Portuguese.

terms: Dutch recognized Portuguese control over Brazil and Angola
Portuguese ceded Ceylon and Malacca to the Dutch
End of official hostilities, though conflicts continued in some regions
impact: Dutch solidified control in the East Indies
Weakened Portuguese global empire, leading to further decline

long_term_effects: Rise of Dutch dominance in the Asian spice trade
Portuguese focus shifted towards defending its remaining colonies
Influence on later European colonial conflicts

economic: End of Portuguese monopoly on the spice trade
Expansion of Dutch economic influence in Asia
political: Rise of the Dutch as a major colonial power
Portuguese Empire's decline, particularly in Asia
social: Cultural exchanges in Brazil and the East Indies
Portuguese and Dutch legacy in local traditions and architecture
